column7: {"notes": "Starship seems to be a major innovation in space flight. This is because it is massively decreasing the cost per kilogram and increasing kilograms to space per year. NASA
column9: seems ot be ignoring Starship. This guy claims the entire industry needs to change some project development patterns because they're based around much longer time horizons and much higher costs per kilogram."}

column7: {"notes": "Banks have slowly been offering more services for free
column8: like free checking accounts initially at relatively high overdraft fees. Those fees are decreasing and lowering for a lot of people. ACH has also increased the speed of settlement for moving money which can be a relatively complex thing. Costs of sending money internationall are also decreasing in terms of raw moeny and time. \" Innovation in finances often starts at the edges of the traditional financial ecosystem but moves in
column9: sometimes gradually and sometiems rapidly. \"" Startups and incumbents both sizably contribute and often the competition between the two drives innovation."}

column7: {"notes": "Small community banks in rural America are the tail that wag the dog and can often limit progress. Sometimes these small banks can innovate and branch (heh) out of their typical business area. Sometimes innovation in banking is regulatory change."}
{"notes": "Scott thinks Hanson's mind is insane because Age of Em is so out there. He thinks the premises are faulty
column8: so the future he talks about won't happen."}

column7: {"notes": "Hanson asks what makes some things like individual cells or species start small or incapable then grow to be bigger and more capable only to later eventually die while only a few species are able to improve. The same is true in sfotware engineering. This is important because as we make global structures
column8: we need to figure out if they'll die out or sustain."}

column1: A Nobel Prize for the Credibility Revolution
column7: {"notes": "The 2021 Nobel Prize was awarded to 3 people for their work popularizing techniques like differencei n differences
column9: and regression discontinuity in economics. They were remarkable not because they were wholly new methods but because they weren't used in economics before
column10: so it opened up the idea of natural experiments in economics. "}

column7: {"notes": "Robin counters Caplan's Virtual Cornucopia by pointing out how many atoms would be needed to support varying numbers of people at varying times higher than subsistence levels"}
{"notes": "Bryan Caplan thinks Robin is pessimistic and that we could have economic growth of 1-10% continue forever in simulations"}
{"notes": "Robin Hanson says that as we find more useful ways to arrange atoms
column8: we'll get rid of all the 'natural' ways atoms are currently arranged"}

column7: {"notes": "Basically
column8: continued economic growth of 2%-7% year over year is not sustainable for (at maximum) 8500 ish more years

column1: On Being That Weird Guy Online

column9: ultimately saying it has opened more valuable opportunities for him on net."}

column1: Against overuse of the Gini coefficient
column7: {"notes": "Post by Vitalik on why Gini isn't good for online communities like crypto. He separates into two problems: one where half the people evenly have half all the wealth and half have 0
column8: and one where one person has half the wealth and the rest share the other half equally; he says tackling each individually is important and proposes some ways to do so: for the first one
column9: a difference between log of average and average of log (utility everyone would have if perfectly distributed minus average utility in economy today); second would be Herfindahl-Hirschman index."}
